Volunteers are provided with saplings and advised to wear appropriate footwear, while limited parking is available at the site.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate for "Someone Else's Skin," praised for its tight writing and exploration of domestic and honor crimes. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career creating detective VI Warshawski, a pioneering female protagonist who influenced perceptions of female writers and founded Sisters In Crime. The awards were presented at North Yorkshire's annual crime writing festival, where Ann Cleeves commended the strong shortlist and highlighted the exceptional quality of Hilary's winning novel.

In 2016, 24-year-old Santner broke his finger during his second game for Worcestershire, impacting the team's qualifying chances as director Steve Rhodes highlighted the loss of player Mitch. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, is set to rejoin the Rapids after participating in the ICC Trophy in England in June. He expressed frustration over his early injury but looks forward to contributing with both bat and ball next summer. Additionally, in August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all game formats.

In 2008, Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was fatally struck by a speeding, unlit car with stolen license plates while attempting to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway. The Exeter coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, ruled his death as unlawful killing, citing evidence of deliberate action despite much being circumstantial. Pring’s wife, Ganna Ziuzina, 19 years his junior, quickly sought to claim his assets and sold his belongings, raising suspicions from his family of a staged hit-and-run. Friends and family alleged Ziuzina had ulterior motives, including an affair and misrepresentation of her occupation. Although Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry, they reopened it in 2011 as a murder investigation, which remains active but not actively pursued. The case highlights the complexities of investigating deaths abroad and the enduring distress experienced by Pring’s family.

Charlie Fearns from Litherland, Merseyside, urgently needs to travel to Seattle Children's Hospital in the USA for experimental T-Cell therapy not available in the UK after his last transplant failed following a third relapse in April. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed immense gratitude and described the anonymous donor who funded the treatment as a "selfless amazing person." The family had been left heartbroken after the initial transplant did not work and saw no treatment options remaining in the UK. With the financial costs covered by the anonymous donation, Charlie has received clearance from the hospital, and his treatment is expected to begin soon, with the start date to be confirmed next week.

Apple has implemented an optional two-factor authentication feature to enhance the security of its iCloud service following incidents where third-party software was used to steal and publicly post celebrities' intimate photos. This security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after their username and password, preventing unauthorized access even if passwords are compromised. Despite its effectiveness, the feature remains opt-in, with experts advocating for it to be enabled by default. Additionally, users can utilize a 14-character recovery key to regain account access if their trusted device is unavailable, though concerns exist about the potential loss or theft of this key. Apple's updates have rendered tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker ineffective, as the company can no longer access iCloud content without the user's device. Apple plans to more actively encourage the adoption of two-factor authentication and the use of stronger passwords to prevent future security breaches.

Dan Groves stated that the specifics of a deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay are yet to be announced. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old Wright will become a club director. Currently, Billericay is eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off position. Wright, known for being the runner-up on "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011 and his non-league football career with clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town, may invest in the club. Recently, multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin took over Billericay, committing to invest £10,000 weekly, and the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr. Ashley has been asked to provide evidence on the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into his company's warehouse practices in Derbyshire. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter requiring Mr. Ashley to respond by March 21. The letter highlights issues regarding the treatment of low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage, which the committee will review over the coming months. Although Mr. Ashley invited the committee to a meeting at the company's Shirebrook base, he has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered and has not agreed to attend. The committee has warned that failure to attend may lead to further actions, including involving the House of Commons over potential contempt. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request, despite previously pledging to review worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight. Additionally, Mr. Ashley is the owner of Newcastle United Football Club.

The opposition, led by Ilya Yashin, is completing an unpublished report titled "Putin. War" that compiles existing facts about Russia's involvement in Ukraine since Crimea's annexation in March 2014 and the eastern conflict. The report argues that President Vladimir Putin orchestrated the war for personal gain by coordinating Russian military support to pro-Russian rebels, despite Russia's claims that such fighters are merely "volunteers." Evidence includes admissions from Russian soldiers about their deployment, documentation of military units and weaponry, and financial data estimating Russia's spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles. The report highlights the significant role of Russian troops in separatist victories and the motivations of volunteer soldiers, who receive substantial salaries. Challenges in publishing the dossier include fear among publishers and limited public interest, with the opposition aiming to extend its initial print run. The report seeks to accuse Putin of directing the war to enhance his popularity, mirroring previous efforts by the late Boris Nemtsov, which did not lead to widespread protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, aged 34 from Wath-Upon-Dearne in Rotherham, was found dead from head injuries at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones criticized the UK government for not sharing the Article 50 letter before its publication and excluding Wales from its drafting, highlighting a lack of respect for devolved administrations. In response, Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns pointed out ongoing discussions and affirmed that the UK government aims to serve the entire nation, including Wales. The letter from Prime Minister Theresa May promises to consult on devolving powers back to the UK regions, intending to increase decision-making authority for devolved administrations. However, uncertainties remain about which specific powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them. Carwyn Jones expressed concerns about potential funding cuts after 2020, while debates continue in Whitehall about transferring powers from the EU to Westminster. Further details are expected in the Great Repeal Bill white paper, but the exact powers to be devolved are still unclear.

On Friday night in Newry's Nursery Drive and Parkhead area, two cars were damaged during attacks on PSNI officers and the community. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the "mindless attacks," and the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were performing their duties when assaulted. The post also urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was removed last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. The board stated he is not expected to return and presented evidence of his illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory remarks, which violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. Charney is pursuing a defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair, which his lawyer claims contains false statements aimed at extorting him. Additionally, American Apparel recently obtained a restraining order preventing Charney from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The upcoming GB basketball game against Greece will be broadcast from 17:30 to 19:30 on BBC iPlayer, the BBC Sport website, and app. Previously, Greece defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, Greece. In the rematch at the Copper Box, three Greek players will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and preparing for EuroBasket 2017. This game is GB's only home match before the EuroBasket begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey. After facing Greece, coach Joe Prunty’s team will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before the championship.

The passage describes the transformative launch of the iPhone by Steve Jobs, highlighting the initial difficulty in accessing the device for media coverage. The author recounts showcasing the iPhone on camera, facing criticism for emphasizing the product launch. Reflecting on the iPhone's impact, the passage explains how it revolutionized photography and daily activities by providing powerful computers in smartphones with user-friendly interfaces. Comparisons are made between traditional digital cameras and smartphones, illustrating the iPhone's role in changing how people use and share technology. The narrative concludes by recognizing the beginning of the mobile connected era and the continued innovation from companies like Amazon and Google.

Toxic substance poisonings in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have resulted in the deaths of four cats within two weeks, including seven-month-old Meereen, who died from ingesting antifreeze. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and urges local residents to safely store pesticides and chemicals, particularly antifreeze used in cars during this season, to prevent further incidents.

Despite the Syriza government in Athens agreeing to implement additional austerity and liberalization measures demanded by creditors, there have been no public protests. Greece's tourism sector is thriving, with Athens airport anticipating 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is negotiating an €86 billion third bailout to address Greece's severe economic challenges, including bank closures and restricted credit access, which threaten further hardship for citizens. Despite continuing fiscal austerity measures, Tsipras remains popular. The success of the new bailout depends on providing hope for recovery, with many experts suggesting that significant debt forgiveness may be necessary for Greece's sustainable economic revival.

Ross Kemp is making a brief return to **EastEnders** as the iconic character Grant Mitchell to participate in the final storyline of Dame Barbara. Barbara, who had previously left the show in 2010, returns to inform her son Phil that her cancer has returned and subsequently dies from the disease in upcoming emotional scenes. Kemp, who portrayed Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, will reunite the Mitchell family, bringing together Grant and his brother Phil. This return aims to deliver classic **EastEnders** moments, highlighting the strong family dynamics and memorable history of the Mitchell brothers.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles last October. Alice’s parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recognized Dhillon as the perpetrator when Northumbria Police informed them of her death. During the Newcastle Crown Court trial, it was revealed that Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and had been stalking her. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice and dismissing warnings from her daughter Emma, who had feared Dhillon would kill Alice. The Ruggles parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and honor Alice’s memory. Dhillon, aged 26, denied murder but was convicted and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

EDF has approved funding for the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear power project in Somerset, with contracts set to be signed soon. However, UK Business Secretary Greg Clark has indicated the government will carefully review the project before providing backing, leading EDF CEO Vincent de Rivaz to cancel a planned visit. Critics raise concerns about environmental impact, rising costs, and significant Chinese investment, which accounts for one-third of the funding. Following EDF's approval, the government initiated an additional review, causing uncertainty and delaying major investment post-Brexit. Industry leaders urge a swift decision to secure energy supplies and meet climate goals, while environmental groups advocate for increased investment in renewable energy instead.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales includes a field asking for the name of the person a spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers warn that naming a third party often increases conflict and complexity, even though the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to do so. The form’s guidance indicates that it is usually unnecessary to provide the adulterous party’s name, but experts believe users may still fill it in due to the form’s design. Naming a third party can delay proceedings and raise costs. In 2015, adultery was cited in over 12,000 of more than 100,000 divorces. Lawyers also caution that involving new partners can negatively impact cases, as courts disapprove of petitioners introducing new relationships into the divorce process.

Ministers are criticized for prioritizing environmental concerns over timber production, despite Britain being the world's third-largest wood importer. Efforts to encourage woodland creation have led to the loss of at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest in Wales since 2001, which Confor warns need replanting to meet demand. The Welsh forestry industry, valued at over £450 million annually, is managed equally by Natural Resources Wales and private companies. Conflicts arise as environmental policies favor native broadleaf species and recreational access, while conservationists oppose commercial forests. Additionally, harvesting challenges and timber transport issues create tensions with local communities. The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social factors through initiatives like the Glastir scheme and the Woodlands for Wales strategy. Confor highlights the need for increased woodland planting and reduced bureaucracy to achieve long-term forestry targets.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews responded to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40 and transported him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko awarded Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, who felt honored but modest about the recognition. Initially, the UK's Foreign Office blocked Russia from honoring the veterans due to regulations against foreign medals awarded after five years. The Russian embassy emphasized the convoys' crucial role in supplying the Soviet Union and defeating Germany on the Eastern Front, highlighting the wartime alliance with Britain. Despite heavy losses, with over 3,000 men perishing and numerous vessels sunk, the British Government established the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize the veterans. In 2013, an exception was made, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the Ushakov medals in London, symbolizing mutual gratitude for the shared wartime efforts.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation identified significant delays in starting community payback for offenders, with many being released without completing their unpaid work. For example, one offender only completed 16 hours in 17 months. In 2014, approximately 70,000 offenders received 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work for crimes like shoplifting and drug offenses. The inspection reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, finding organizational challenges in managing individuals with chaotic lives and substance issues. The report presented 15 recommendations, including reducing the number of offenders turned away when they report on time and tailoring unpaid work objectives to each offender's circumstances. While some high-quality programs and positive attitudes among offenders were noted, the chief inspector criticized the system for viewing unpaid work merely as punishment and called for urgent improvements. The Ministry of Justice responded by accepting all recommendations and committing to implement them to ensure more effective rehabilitation and enforcement of court-ordered unpaid work.

The newspaper accused comedian Brand of hypocrisy for advocating economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxurious London home, a frequent criticism against him. During a campaign supporting East London residents threatened by gentrification, a reporter questioned his own accommodations, prompting Brand to call the journalist "a snide" and walk away. Although contacted about potential legal action against The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, Brand did not respond but criticized the newspaper on Twitter using #TheSunLogic. He has previously addressed such accusations by acknowledging his wealth and emphasizing the need for personal and systemic change to address economic disparity and ecological issues.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping by turning it into a competitive race, earning both acclaim and criticism for his assertive approach. After publishing the human genome, he focused on creating synthetic life, resulting in the organism Synthia through the J Craig Venter Institute. Venter's innovative methods, such as utilizing messenger RNA for gene sequencing, led him to establish The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, challenging traditional scientific practices. Additionally, he conducted extensive genetic research in marine environments aboard his yacht, aiming to sequence diverse microbial genomes. Venter's work in synthetic biology aims to revolutionize industry and environmental sustainability by developing microbes that can reduce oil dependence and capture carbon dioxide.

A survey of approximately 1,000 English parents revealed that 80% of children who ate school lunches tried new foods at school, with half requesting these dishes to be prepared at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least favored. Commissioned by England's School Food Trust following a Mumsnet survey, the research highlighted the role of school meals in introducing variety and healthier options to children's diets. About 40% of primary school children in England and 46% in Scotland participate in school lunch programs. The online survey was conducted between February 26 and March 5 among parents with children aged 4–17 years.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker competing in Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His transfer included Real's option to buy him back for up to €30 million. Previously targeted by Arsenal and Chelsea, Morata has scored three goals for Spain and 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He featured in consecutive Champions League finals, winning with Real in 2014 as a substitute and scoring in Juventus' 3–1 loss to Barcelona in 2015. Standing at 6 ft 3 in, Morata emerged from Real's youth system, making his first-team debut at 18 and scoring 10 La Liga goals.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013. During his second spell at the City Ground, the 30-year-old made 51 appearances after spending four seasons with the club before signing for Celtic. Since being released in May, he has been without a team and has previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant and world’s third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain, which operates 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007. As part of the deal, around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business managed by Los Angeles-based private equity firm Yucaipa, led by billionaire Ron Burkle. Tesco will loan Yucaipa approximately £80 million and incur a £150 million cost to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, part of which may be repaid. Additionally, 50 Fresh & Easy stores will be closed. If Yucaipa succeeds and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. This move marks Tesco’s orderly and efficient exit from the US market following its first annual profit decline in 20 years reported in April.

The passage describes an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a guide on how to get into martial arts.

From the late 1960s to the late 2000s, glaciers in the French Alps, including the Mont Blanc Massif, decreased from approximately 375 sq km to about 275 sq km, marking a 26% reduction over 40 years. Marie Gardent and her team conducted a new glaciers inventory using map archives, satellite imagery, and manual inspections to ensure accuracy, particularly where debris or shadows obscured glacier margins. The retreat of glaciers has been uneven, with the southern sectors like the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs experiencing more significant losses than the northern Alps, likely due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions such as less precipitation and cloud cover. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has also slightly diminished in area. Ongoing research presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting aligns with similar findings of accelerated glacier retreat across the broader Alpine region.

The Scottish women's football team has won all five qualifiers and is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, where a victory would nearly secure their place in next summer's finals in the Netherlands without needing a play-off. Coach Evans, motivated by past play-off defeats, emphasized the team's ambition to reach major competitions and highlighted the advantage of having 12 players competing in top international leagues, including Bayern Munich. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland and unbeaten in four matches, poses a crucial challenge that will determine the group's ranking. Evans credited the experience gained from playing abroad for enhancing the national team's performance and expressed optimism about qualifying for the finals.

Stuart Campbell, a Stirling-born blogger and Scottish independence advocate living in Bath, was arrested in west England on Friday after a woman in her 30s from south London filed a harassment complaint. The allegation involves online harassment through tweets over a two-year period. Campbell, a former computer games reviewer and founder of the Wings Over Scotland blog launched in 2011, was released on bail pending further inquiries until mid-September. He stated that the tweets were not threatening and criticized the media for promoting speculation. Additionally, Campbell announced on Twitter that he would be posting less frequently due to reasons beyond his control.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) has proposed replacing Skegness's traditional mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a more animal-friendly version—a fish accompanied by the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." PETA argues that the current mascot symbolizes animal cruelty, depicting harmful practices like fish impaling and overcrowded nets. They believe this change would help rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination that does not celebrate the mutilation and killing of sea animals. In response, Skegness Mayor Carl Macey acknowledged the suggestions but expressed skepticism about the support for removing Jolly, emphasizing that the mascot is beloved and has not been perceived as promoting animal cruelty. He stated that the proposal would be reviewed by the council but indicated a preference to maintain the existing mascot unless significant issues arise.

Scotland triumphed over Georgia with a decisive 38-11 victory in their rugby match. Scotland scored six tries through Tommy Seymour, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice), Hamish Watson, and Ali Price, all converted by Greig Laidlaw. Georgia managed two penalty tries by Vasil Lobzhanidze but struggled to maintain possession and control, holding only 9% of it by halftime. Key moments included disciplinary actions against Georgia's Kote Mikautadze and Scotland's Moray Low. Scotland dominated possession and territory, effectively managing the game despite a late effort from Georgia. Coach Vern Cotter praised the team's pragmatic and improved performance under Laidlaw's leadership.

Widnes secured a victory over Castleford with a final score of 38-15. Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor contributed to Widnes' lead, which reached 14-6 by halftime. Despite Castleford's Paddy Flynn scoring three tries, including a hat-trick, Widnes maintained their advantage. The win moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained sixth, just one point ahead of the Vikings. This defeat marked Castleford's fourth consecutive home league loss, following nine losses in their last ten matches.

Fawzi al-Odah, aged 37, was released from the US Guantanamo facility in Cuba after a review panel determined he was not a continuing significant threat. Detained since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on alleged links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—a charge he denies—al-Odah had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Upon his release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and expressed no bitterness, only joy. Although freed from Guantanamo, he is required to spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His departure reduces the number of inmates at the facility to 148 and marks the first release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. The US naval base in Cuba, established in January 2002 after the September 11 attacks, remains open despite President Barack Obama's promises to shut it down.

Thousands attended the early morning Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner, which included a parade of up to 400 participants and a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War I, specifically the Gallipoli landings. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, featuring the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia. Since its first commemoration in 1916 with King George V's attendance, Anzac Day has become an important occasion for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. The ceremonies included speeches highlighting the courage and heroism of Anzac troops, participation from veterans and their families, prayers, and community involvement.

Clarkson, 30, has returned to Premiership Well for a second time in July and is expected to make his St Mirren debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. Last season, he scored nine goals for Dundee, primarily as a substitute. With nearly 400 senior club appearances and previous roles at Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, Clarkson has also been capped twice for Scotland, scoring once. He emphasizes his fitness and readiness to contribute, aiming to help St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship and seven points above bottom side Alloa, gain confidence and improve their standing.

Ranjit Boparan acquired Bernard Matthews, addressing workers' pension concerns by guaranteeing that all existing agreements would be honored. Unite confirmed that the closed final salary pension scheme from 2004 remains unaffected, and the current pension arrangements will continue under Boparan’s ownership. Boparan aims to restore Bernard Matthews to high profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and expanding operations to process both chicken and turkeys.

At a council meeting addressing problems with the new Cowes ferry, Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would remain free until July 2 to acknowledge issues and gather feedback. Since its launch on May 14, the ferry has faced breakdowns, run aground, and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Additionally, cars have been damaged during boarding and unboarding, and local businesses like Valu-4-U have suffered significant losses from reduced trade. The council has ordered an audit review of the project and is discussing compensation for affected businesses. Transport Councillor Ian Ward described the situation as typical for a prototype, mentioning that electrical problems have been fixed, ramp extensions have been approved to prevent vehicle damage, and seamanship issues leading to groundings have been resolved.

The House of Lords warns that post-Brexit, the UK might need to permit EU fishing boats in its waters despite regional support for leaving the EU and the fishing industry's aim to regain control and increase exports. Although the fishing sector contributes minimally to the UK’s GDP and employment, it risks being sidelined in Brexit negotiations. Maintaining market access is crucial, potentially requiring concessions such as allowing more EU boats in exchange for tariff-free fish exports. Shared fish stocks and the need for continued cooperation add complexity. Recent EU quota increases have been positively received by the industry, which remains hopeful about greater control and sustainable management of UK waters after Brexit. The government seeks to balance maximizing trade freedom with ensuring sustainable fisheries management.

Timothy Geaney admitted to possessing or allowing the acquisition of images between April 2004 and February 2014. Earlier this year, he received a community payback order and was placed on the sex offenders register. Following a hearing by the General Teaching Council Scotland, he was removed from the professional teaching register. The Dumfries Sheriff Court revealed that most downloaded images depicted young boys in partially dressed erotic poses without sexual activity. In addition to his payback order, Geaney was mandated to participate in a specialized program for sex offenders. The hearing concluded that his actions violated child protection standards and demonstrated a consistent pattern of misconduct, deeming him unfit to teach. At 69 years old, Geaney was barred from re-registering as a teacher for two years.

A fire on March 2 at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site caused train service reductions and travel delays. Following the blaze, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, citing enforcement action despite the firm being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws and having nine prior inspections by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service. The EA's decision, effective August 7 unless appealed, revokes the environmental permit, requiring the company to cease operations at the site and remove all waste. The fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Syria is striving to adhere to the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons but missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad reported that two shipments were sent to the port of Latakia, with the second being attacked by terrorist groups. He criticized US condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where reports indicate significant civilian casualties. Conflicting accounts exist regarding the control of Aleppo's central prison, with rebels allegedly seizing it and freeing detainees, while the Syrian government denies these claims. The United States has noted that only about 4% of Syria's 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons have been removed, expressing concern over delays. Russia has urged Syria to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by March 1. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) cited security issues as a reason for the slowed destruction process. Syria reaffirmed its commitment to fulfilling all obligations with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

England secured a commanding victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the four-match series with a day to spare. Batting first, England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, marking their second-largest run win against Pakistan. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook also contributed significantly with scores of 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan struggled with their batting, being bowled out for 198 and 234, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq surpassing 50 runs in the first two Tests. England's disciplined batting and effective bowling were highlighted, and they are expected to continue their strong performance in the upcoming third Test.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is seeking input from pensioners, their families, and friends about residential care experiences to inform her review on the quality of life and care for older adults in Welsh residential care. The review will evaluate factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, aiming to highlight both positive and negative aspects of care. While her efforts are supported by groups like Care Forum Wales, some, including its chair Mario Kreft, have criticized the advisory panel for lacking representation from care providers, believing this exclusion misses opportunities for effective partnership and sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former midfielder who played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, has been appointed Aberdeen's manager, succeeding Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Since 2010, Sheerin served as player-manager for Arbroath (the Red Lichties), leading them to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division and achieving promotion in 2011. Despite Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two in the 2013-14 season, Aberdeen's chief executive Duncan Fraser selected Sheerin after a comprehensive search, valuing his desire to return to the club. Additionally, Sheerin earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s before transitioning into coaching.

Following the dismissal of Bob Bradley, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea in their upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club is keen to appoint a new manager swiftly, with Paul Clement being the preferred candidate. Curtis expressed concerns about potential relegation and the difficulty of achieving promotion back to the Premier League. He reflected on Swansea's rise to prominence after their 2011 promotion and attributed the club's decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 to frequent management changes and loss of key players. Despite these challenges, Curtis is confident in the current squad's ability to remain in the Premier League and emphasized the significance of maintaining their status for both the club and the local community.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the race to map the human genome into a competitive endeavor, earning both criticism and recognition within the scientific community. Known for his outspoken nature and affluent lifestyle, Venter accelerated human genomics by pioneering methods that focused on messenger RNA, significantly increasing gene sequencing rates. After leaving the NIH due to criticism from figures like James Watson, he founded the Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, successfully publishing the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995 and contributing to the human genome project in 2001. In 2006, Venter established the J. Craig Venter Institute, which achieved a landmark in synthetic biology by creating the first synthetic life form, Synthia. Additionally, he embarked on ambitious projects to sequence marine microbial genomes, aiming to advance understanding of gene and protein functions. Despite controversies over his unconventional approaches, Venter's work has had a profound impact on genomics and synthetic biology, with potential implications for environmental sustainability and industrial innovation.

The Sutton Trust warns that England's apprenticeships are often low quality and short compared to other European countries like Germany. Their study by Boston Consulting Group found that out of 520,000 annual apprenticeships in England, fewer than 200,000 are at level three (A-level equivalent), and only 20% of employers offer apprenticeships, much lower than Germany's 51%. Most apprenticeships target individuals over 25 rather than young people, with intense competition for limited spots. The report advocates expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new positions each year, primarily at level three or higher, to boost the economy and improve job prospects for youth. While the Department for Education claims to be reforming apprenticeships to raise standards, the Association of Colleges emphasizes the need to preserve respected level two apprenticeships and enhance vocational education quality. The report highlights the inadequacy of England's vocational system and calls for a more streamlined and valued approach to apprenticeships.

Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, has earned 22 medals in cycling and swimming over six Paralympics. Recently, she finished more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and is aiming to win her 17th title in Saturday's road race. At 37, Storey targets further success at next year's Rio de Janeiro Games. She secured four golds at the 2012 London Paralympics and has won 21 world titles. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford Bulls were expelled from the Conference Premier on June 10, 2014, after failing to pay £148,000 in debts despite multiple deadline extensions and a takeover by businessman Tommy Agombar. Financial struggles, intensified by declining attendance since their 2012 relegation, led to their replacement by Chester FC, while Hayes & Yeading remained in Conference South. Efforts by the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to purchase and save the club were unsuccessful, resulting in the Bulls' removal from the league and leaving supporters disheartened.

Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England after debuting in 2009. He was part of two World Cup and two European Championship squads, playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most England Under-21 appearances with 46 caps since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He also publicly supported Sam Allardyce, wishing success to the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and a leading figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a several-month illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for approximately 30 years and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and the acclaimed 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood collaborated with prominent orchestras worldwide and held positions such as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. Academically, he was a tutor at Harvard, an honorary professor at Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. Praised for his generosity and significant contributions to historically informed music, Hogwood was highly respected by colleagues and students alike. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be announced later.

A boy from Northern Ireland remains unnamed to protect his identity as his family navigates challenges related to his education needs. In June, his parents withdrew him from mainstream school due to his difficulties and sought placement in a special school, but all available schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were at full capacity with no expected openings. His mother expressed his frustration over being isolated while his siblings attend school. Recently, a local special school hired an additional classroom assistant, offering hope for his enrollment in the coming weeks. Nonetheless, the family fears that the limited capacity of special schools will continue to affect other families. The Education Authority stated they cannot discuss individual cases to protect privacy but are reviewing special school placement needs in Northern Ireland to improve future placements starting from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has launched a takeover bid for the Newport Gwent Dragons, aiming to designate Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue. Shareholders will vote on this takeover on May 9. County Football Club holds a lease that prioritizes its fixtures at Rodney Parade until 2023 and expects the contract to be honored. Newport RFC and Newport Squash Club are also protected under existing agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. On the sporting front, County is close to avoiding relegation from League Two and could secure their status this weekend. Relegation would significantly impact both the club and the city of Newport.

Last weekend, the country was declared free of a virus that caused nearly 4,000 deaths over the past 18 months. A survivor shared his harrowing experience of being kidnapped by Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the civil war (1991-2002), enduring brutal treatment, and eventually escaping to rebuild his life with the help of Lifeline Nehemiah. In 2014, during the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, he and others established a clinic that saved many lives through community education, providing food and support, and setting up an Ebola treatment unit despite initial resistance and limited funds. The Ebola outbreak resulted in 11,314 deaths across several countries, including Liberia (4,808), Sierra Leone (3,955), Guinea (2,536), Nigeria (8), the US (1), and Mali (6).

A fundraising campaign successfully prevented the auction of approximately 80,000 Wedgwood artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs needed to settle the pottery firm's pension debt. Led by the Art Fund, the campaign reached its target within a month, ensuring the collection remains displayed at the Barlaston Museum in Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrators and supporters highlighted the collection's cultural importance to Britain and expressed satisfaction with preserving it from being sold and dispersed globally.

Dan Groves stated that details of a potential deal for Wright to purchase a 20% stake in the club have yet to be disclosed. According to The Sun, the 30-year-old Wright will become a club director. Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, known for being the runner-up in "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, has played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who committed to investing £10,000 weekly. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

Blackpool and Colchester United ended their match in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute when Jamille Matt scored after Nathan Delfouneso's precise pass. Colchester equalized through Kurtis Guthrie from a corner following a save by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe. Both teams had multiple opportunities to win the game, including a missed chance by Blackpool's Tom Aldred. The match concluded with Colchester United reducing to ten men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the disused Fawley Power Station site into a £1 billion "merchant city" development, featuring a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, and restaurants. The iconic 198-meter-high chimney, which made the station the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, will remain as the centerpiece. The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971 and capable of powering one million homes, was closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation. The 300-acre site, sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016, will also include fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Building could commence in 2018 following an outline planning permission application expected later this year.

At the Hong Kong Championships, Great Britain earned multiple cycling medals. A 23-year-old GB cyclist won bronze in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Adrian Teklinski of Poland secured gold, and Lucass Liss of Germany took silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB was surpassed by Italy for the bronze medal. Joe Truman, GB's sole competitor in the men's keirin, was eliminated in the semi-finals. The women's team pursuit, led by Barker along with Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, finished fifth in the heats and did not compete for bronze. Additionally, Olympic bronze medalist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint but is set to participate in two more events, aiming to prepare for Tokyo.

Ross Kemp, who portrayed Grant Mitchell on "EastEnders" from 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, is making a brief return to the show for the final episodes of Barbara Mitchell. Barbara, Grant and Phil Mitchell's mother, has reappeared to inform Phil that her cancer has returned and will lead to her death in upcoming spring episodes. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell family as they confront Barbara's passing. "EastEnders" executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted Grant Mitchell as a legendary character, emphasizing that this reunion will showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best during emotional and pivotal moments in the series.

Sadio Mane scored two goals within 138 seconds, leading to a disappointing defeat for second-placed Spurs at Anfield. Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire to win and poor away form, noting they have won only twice on the road since September and struggled against top-six opponents. He warned that if Chelsea extend their lead by 12 points, it would create significant challenges for Spurs in the Premier League race. Additionally, former midfielder Danny Murphy highlighted Spurs' defensive inconsistencies and lack of pace away from home, emphasizing the need for immediate improvement.

In recent elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor positions, marking the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP)'s largest defeat since 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost key northern states, including Katsina and Kaduna, and control of Adamawa, but retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mainly in the south-east. The APC's victories have reduced the PDP to a regional party, although the APC did not secure any of Nigeria's major oil-producing states. Despite some election-related violence, the process was generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP now faces challenges of rebuilding amid corruption allegations, defections to the APC, and difficulties in addressing Islamist insurgencies.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will be held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22. This year’s lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Attendees can use a dedicated app to access augmented reality features, triggering online information from signs and posters, and view videos and band interviews on their phones and tablets. According to HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan, the app enhances the festival experience for visitors and allows people worldwide to interact with the event, access information, buy tickets, and experience the festival’s atmosphere remotely.

Several Birmingham schools, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, were rated inadequate by Ofsted, leading to the termination of their funding agreements. Park View Educational Trust may lose control of these institutions, while Oldknow and Golden Hillock were warned to address specific concerns to retain funding. Issues highlighted include inadequate safety measures against extremism and the use of unvetted speakers in Islamic-themed assemblies. Education Minister Lord Nash criticized the trusts for not promoting inclusive development and set a July 4 deadline for necessary improvements, such as ending discriminatory practices and ensuring a balanced curriculum. A head teacher reported that parents attempted to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection, contributing to feelings of isolation and questioning her effectiveness. Ofsted released reports alleging a culture of fear and targeted campaigns to impose a narrow faith-based ideology in these schools. Parents and local officials have challenged the Ofsted findings, accusing inspectors of bias and urging a review of the assessments.

Vincent Barker died in July 2012 five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose is charged with gross negligence manslaughter for allegedly failing to detect Barker's swollen optic discs and not referring him for further investigation, which led to fluid buildup in his brain and his death. Ms. Rose denies the charge, and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court for coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he met through an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day and was placed on the sex offenders register. Despite denying the charges, Weatherhogg was found guilty and the case was referred to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. The judge highlighted society's strong disapproval of his actions, noting that Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, posed a moderate risk of re-offending. Weatherhogg expressed shock at being placed on remand before sentencing.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41*), and captain William Porterfield (39) making significant contributions. Afghanistan successfully chased the target, reaching 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) leading the innings, securing victory with two overs remaining. Ireland faced an early setback when opener Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2 wickets, the only bowler to do so. The teams will compete again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday. Additionally, Ireland’s paceman Boyd Rankin missed the T20s due to a back problem but is expected to return for the upcoming five ODIs against Afghanistan starting March 15.

Barcelona's summer acquisition of Neymar from Santos cost £48.6 million, with total expenses reaching £106.8 million when including fees and taxes. The club faces accusations of financial misconduct related to the transfer, leading to the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell, who denies wrongdoing. A Spanish judge has allowed investigations to continue, while Barcelona denies any tax-related crimes and has submitted an additional tax declaration of €13.55 million. Meanwhile, Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for the team this season.

On September 15, the bodies of 24-year-old David Miller and 23-year-old Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao. UK Metropolitan Police collaborated with Thai authorities, who have detained two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, alleged to have confessed to the murders. The suspects face charges of conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment during the investigation. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with DNA evidence linking the suspects to the crimes. UK detectives are returning to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families.

Scotland’s women’s football team, undefeated in all five qualifiers, is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, where a win would nearly guarantee their spot in the next summer’s finals without needing a play-off. Coach Evans, determined to avoid repeating past play-off disappointments for Euro 2013 and the last World Cup, emphasized the team’s ambition to reach major competitions. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland and also unbeaten, poses a crucial challenge in determining the group leader. The Scottish squad benefits from having 12 players competing in top international leagues, including Evans at Bayern Munich, whose experiences abroad enhance the national team’s capabilities as they strive for their first major finals.

Recent reports suggest that third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, was used to steal celebrities' intimate photos from iCloud. In response, Apple has implemented enhanced security measures, including two-factor authentication (2FA) that requires a four-digit code or a 14-character recovery key when accessing iCloud from new devices. Although 2FA remains an opt-in feature, experts recommend making it the default to improve security. Apple's updates also notify account owners via email when a backup is downloaded. While these changes prevent unauthorized access using the previously exploited software, concerns persist about the usability and security of recovery keys. Apple plans to encourage more users to adopt 2FA and stronger passwords to further protect accounts.

During the campaign period from January 23 to May 22, UKIP won the election by spending £2,956,737, averaging 68p per of their 4,376,635 votes. The Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote), Labour spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote) and came in second, while the Lib Dems allocated £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) but lost all but one of their MEPs. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote) on 1,255,573 votes. Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087 on their campaigns. All parties except Labour increased their spending compared to the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson (27) has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals and may face his former club on February 18. Striker Keating (21), recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, joins the Gulls after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson’s leadership and Keating’s determination. Currently, the Gulls are four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite having no significant underlying health issues and previous treatments for overheating, Many Clouds showed no post-race ataxia symptoms on the day of the race. The British Horseracing Authority described such incidents as rare and is committed to understanding and preventing them. Trainer Oliver Sherwood hailed Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime," and the report concluded that the death was due to a rarely seen haemorrhage unrelated to his past conditions.

Several Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) are retiring ahead of the May 5 election. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears during farewell speeches by departing MSPs Duncan McNeil, Alasdair Salmond, and Annabel Goldie. Alasdair Salmond, former First Minister, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the parliament's increasing governance responsibilities, while critiquing the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling unionist promises. Duncan McNeil stressed the need for Holyrood to adopt Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability. Annabel Goldie shared lighthearted memories of working with Finance Secretary John Swinney. All three are stepping down after significant careers in the Scottish Parliament.

The film, set to release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, features Dame Angela Lansbury as Mrs. Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson stars as Belle, with Dan Stevens portraying the Beast and Luke Evans as the villainous Gaston. Josh Gad joins as Gaston's sidekick, LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, known for *Dreamgirls* and the last two *Twilight* films, production will begin at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with relatives of the 96 victims of the 1989 Hillsborough disaster at 11:00 BST to announce its plans. Last year's inquests determined that the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, evidence concerning 23 suspects—15 from the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes during the FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest, and eight from a police conduct probe—was referred to the CPS for possible charges. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall whose son died, are seeking accountability and are awaiting the CPS's decisions at the private meeting in Warrington.

Chelmsford Prison has faced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, leading to widespread issues with contraband such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, as highlighted by a former inmate. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the staff's significant efforts to prevent contraband but emphasizes the need for additional measures. Consequently, the Justice Secretary is exploring ways to equip prisons better to address this problem. A local resident reported witnessing four package-throwing incidents in two weeks and is involved in discussions with the prison about potential solutions. While a former inmate suggested that drones are used to smuggle goods into the prison, the Ministry of Justice stated there is no evidence supporting drone usage at the Chelmsford site. Additionally, new laws have been introduced that allow individuals who smuggle packages over prison walls to be jailed for up to two years.

In December, Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old long-serving lollipop lady, was seriously injured when Brian Wright, aged 55 from Kempston, failed to stop at a red light and struck her outside Bedford Road Lower School. Wright admitted to hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denied that his dangerous driving caused her severe injuries, attributing his failure to stop to being blinded by the setting sun. Blackburn, who had been escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road, is now receiving treatment in residential care. During the Luton Crown Court hearing, Wright expressed deep remorse for his actions, acknowledging the impact on Blackburn and her family. The judge allowed a brief pause for Wright to compose himself after his emotional testimony. The trial is ongoing.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, secured fourth and sixth places in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07. Despite her passion for representing Scotland, she will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast to focus on her final year of veterinary medicine studies, with exams scheduled for May. Muir expressed her disappointment but emphasized the importance of her education and indicated plans to target future competitions, including the World Indoor Championships in March. She remains optimistic about her athletic future, believing she has two to three more Olympics ahead.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 while walking home from a Christmas party in County Kildare. Gardaí have initiated a search in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed his case and enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely speaking with an unidentified man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street and being followed on Haddington Road. Despite releasing the footage and appealing for the man's identification, he has not yet been identified.

Del Potro defeated Switzerland’s Stan Wawrinka with scores of 3-6, 6-3, 7-6(7-2), 6-3, marking his return to Grand Slam tennis after over two years of injuries and placing him 165th in the rankings. He expressed his happiness about playing again and will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Additionally, Australia's Nick Kyrgios overcame Germany's Dustin Brown in a five-set, rain-affected match and is set to play Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with a potential matchup against Andy Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Routine victories were also achieved by Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia was threatened with expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after disputing a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. Following their apology to Caf, their participation was reinstated, allowing them a chance to make their thirteenth consecutive appearance. Similarly, Morocco faced a ban from the 2017 tournament after withdrawing as hosts in 2015 over Ebola fears, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced their fine. Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa expressed optimism for the future of African and Moroccan football. Both teams have been drawn into their respective groups for the 2017 Nations Cup in Gabon, signaling their return to competition after resolving disputes with Caf.

McLaren, historically a dominant Formula 1 team with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling, positioned near the back of the grid due to issues with their Honda power unit. The team’s decline began in 2013 following chassis design problems and has been compounded by scandals in 2007 and 2009. Despite these challenges, under the leadership of Ron Dennis, McLaren is optimistic about a resurgence, supported by a strong car, a renewed Honda partnership, and drivers like Fernando Alonso. Dennis believes the team is on the path to reclaiming its past success and achieving future championships.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven around 06:00 BST. Police later discovered that alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts, and James Thomas faced one count of permitting liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge criticized the management practices and O'Neill's record, imposing fines of £3,000 for O'Neill and £1,000 for Thomas.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season by hitting eight, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Alongside Klay Thompson’s 26 points, the Warriors overcame a 13-point deficit, preventing their first three-game losing streak of the season. In other games, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78 after overcoming a 19-point halftime deficit. Pau Gasol contributed 16 points and 15 rebounds, while Derrick Rose added 12 points in his comeback from injury, helping the Bulls move back to third place in the Eastern Conference.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Melwood. Initially thought to be a competition winner receiving a dead-ball masterclass, van Velzen demonstrated his impressive free-kick skills, catching the players off guard. Throughout the session, van Velzen showcased his abilities, including scoring a top corner strike and eliciting reactions from the Liverpool stars. He enjoyed the experience of interacting with the players and revealed Balotelli's infamous slogan and his famous t-shirt from a 2011 match.

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that women with the BRCA1 gene who underwent an oophorectomy (ovary removal) experienced a 62% reduction in breast cancer mortality and a 65% decrease in death from all causes. Performing the surgery within two years of diagnosis resulted in a 73% lower risk of death for BRCA1 carriers. Angelina Jolie exemplified this approach by having both a double mastectomy and an oophorectomy, which significantly lowered her risk of dying from breast cancer. The researchers suggest that oophorectomy should be included in treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer, especially for those with estrogen-receptor negative tumors.

On Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33) were fatally struck by Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, shortly before 10 a.m. as they remained on the railroad tracks. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for nearly three hours on Norfolk Southern property following the accident. Authorities reported that none of the 166 passengers were injured, though one individual received treatment after falling ill during the delay. Witnesses indicated that the couple might have been living in a nearby homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. His efforts were instrumental in prosecuting figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. After retiring due to declining health, the DEA has refused to grant him citizenship, leaving Toro in the U.S. illegally and facing deportation. Fearing for his safety if returned to Colombia, Toro is seeking a green card or passport while unable to receive social security benefits. Former colleagues have provided financial assistance for his medical needs after the DEA declined to help.

The U.S. internet regulatory body, ICANN, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for using the “.sucks” domain to charge high fees—approximately $2,499 annually—to celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies seeking to remove offensive domain names such as youtube.sucks and bing.sucks. Initially approved by ICANN, the “.sucks” domain faces backlash from major industry groups who label it a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." Vox Populi claims its practices comply with ICANN rules and the law, but ICANN is assessing whether the company's actions are illegal and may enforce contract breaches or other remedies if violations are found.

Twenty-seven years after her stillborn baby boy's body was discovered in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, a mother was arrested following a DNA-led investigation. Police exhumed the body during a case review, and DNA matches identified her as the mother. She admitted to concealing her pregnancy and placing the stillborn baby in the pond on June 5, 1988. Although charges of infanticide were dropped after she explained the circumstances, she remains on bail for potentially failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, named Peter, was reburied at the local church, and authorities have ruled out any foul play.

Five years ago, in Bath, Somerset, 23-year-old Kristopher Hicks was severely injured after jumping from a moving taxi driven by Michael Young, 56. Mr. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks intended to skip the fare and unlawfully detained him by driving for nearly a mile. When Hicks resisted, he exited the speeding vehicle at over 20 mph, sustaining devastating brain injuries, epilepsy, and requiring constant care from his mother. The Hicks family took Mr. Young to the High Court, where Judge Edis ruled that the driver had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to compensation. The settlement is expected to be approximately half of the family's initial claim, along with £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both parties have the right to appeal the decision.

Several tornadoes were reported in Kansas on Wednesday night, including one northwest of Goddard near Wichita, which ultimately missed the city but threatened nearby areas. Southwestern Kansas, around Aetna, also experienced tornado sightings. Missouri's Potosi town saw possible tornado-induced wind damage and flooding. Social media highlighted fallen trees, roof damage, and large hail. CNN experts warned of ongoing nighttime storms throughout the night, with more severe weather expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes regions.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey on Saturday, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold plans to dominate Machida by adopting a "bull" strategy, focusing on cutting off the ring and exploiting Machida's limited opportunities for success, especially on the ground. Both fighters express mutual respect, with Rockhold acknowledging Machida's status in the sport while emphasizing his own mixed martial arts skills. Machida, coming off a win against CB Dollaway, is confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and secure a title opportunity, highlighting his preparation and technical approach. Both competitors are prepared and optimistic about their chances, each seeking to advance to a championship fight.

An 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, inadvertently performed a belly landing in Fort Pierce, Florida, when his light general aviation aircraft touched down without deploying its landing gear. The incident, captured on video, showed the plane skidding along the runway with damaged propellers and bouncing wings. Realizing the mistake, Mr. Georgaklis re-engaged the engines, took off, and safely flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale with his dog, Buddy. The FAA is investigating the occurrence, which is typically caused by human error or mechanical failures.

Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's underwhelming performances but committed to supporting the Manchester City midfielder until the season's end. Despite Manchester City struggling with only 18 points from 39 and plans to refresh their aging squad, the club remains open to offers for Toure in the summer. Pellegrini, facing his own future uncertainties, emphasized Toure's importance to the team. Additionally, teammate Joe Hart highlighted the players' responsibility for poor results while supporting Pellegrini. Separately, Sam Allardyce cautioned Aaron Cresswell against transferring to Manchester City despite the club's interest.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65-year-old Sicilian mafia member known as the "godfather of Uxbridge," has been allowed to remain in the UK after his extradition to Italy was halted. Convicted in absentia in 1999 by an Italian court for his involvement with Cosa Nostra, Rancadore faced a seven-year sentence. Although he lost his extradition case in February 2024, his European arrest warrant was withdrawn in October 2023 after his case expired, as Italian law extinguishes convictions after more than double the sentence period has passed. Legal experts criticized the lengthy and costly extradition process, describing it as a "waste of time and money." Rancadore’s solicitor expressed confidence that he would be discharged, allowing him to live peacefully in the UK with his family. The case may still be reviewed by the Italian Supreme Court, but for now, Rancadore remains in Britain without being extradited.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown. The other contenders include Irish Raider Special Tiara, Sacre (trained by Nicky Henderson and ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury), and Somersby trained by Mick Channon. This race will mark McCoy's final Grade One ride following his retirement announcement after winning with Mr Mole at Newbury in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was discovered 33 days after her disappearance, and Ritter was initially advised not to view the body or crime scene photos. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. After decades of avoiding the crime scene photos, Ritter recently viewed them and now expresses a desire for revenge.

Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters at Augusta to complete the career grand slam, viewing it as essential and unthinkable not to achieve. Reflecting on his significant final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011, he considers that day the most important of his career, which taught him valuable lessons. McIlroy aims to join the elite group of players who have won all four major titles, emphasizing his focus on playing his best rather than the potential accolades. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he remains optimistic about claiming his first green jacket. McIlroy also sees Augusta as a sanctuary where he can concentrate on his game amidst the tournament's pressure and hype, hoping to overcome past setbacks and achieve his long-term goals.

Last week’s trending stories included:

- A rare sighting of four rainbows in New York, captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis.
- The growing trend of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China, now targeted by a national crackdown on vice.
- Robert Downey Jr.'s frustration during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life.
- The rise of the #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend, aiming to mimic Kylie Jenner’s look.
- 102-year-old Alice Barker’s bomb-themed prom-posal, which led to accusations of racism from school administrators.
- Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," generating significant social media interest.
- Johnny Depp’s drastic transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer.
- Creative pregnancy announcements referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and a military dad photobombing his son.
  
These diverse stories captured significant online attention throughout the week.

New figures reveal that 272 children in England were hospitalized last year due to fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), though experts believe the actual number affected by prenatal alcohol exposure could be significantly higher, potentially around 7,500 annually. Research by the World Health Organization indicates that at least one in 100 UK babies may experience learning, behavioral, and physical issues from alcohol exposure in the womb. Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome emphasizes that FAS is a severe, under-diagnosed problem with lifelong impacts. The passage also highlights the personal story of a teenager with FAS and discusses additional medical complications linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy. While the government currently advises limited alcohol intake for pregnant women, Mitchell advocates for a complete prohibition of alcohol during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old former juvenile offender nicknamed "boomerang boy," was sentenced to six years in prison for attempting to rob a Shildon post office and stores in County Durham on March 15. During the robbery, McKerry brandished an axe and demanded cash but was subdued when store owner Sab Dhillon tackled him and his wife, Sam Dhillon, struck him twice with a baseball bat, causing him to drop the weapon. McKerry has a long criminal history, starting shoplifting at age 12 and accumulating numerous arrests and convictions over the years.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35)—are charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party in a Canadian naval barracks in Nova Scotia. They appeared in a Dartmouth courtroom where bail was set at over £2,000 each, requiring them to surrender their passports, remain employed by the Royal Navy, and reside on the Stadacona naval base near Halifax until their trial on May 27. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after a hockey game at the Shearwater naval base. The charges, which include sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, carry penalties of up to 14 years in prison. Canadian military investigators are continuing the investigation, and the sailors will stay in Nova Scotia until their case is resolved.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, one of only 70 cases worldwide. This rare congenital skin disease causes his skin to appear red, scaly, and inflamed, resembling burn marks. To manage his condition, Valerie regularly applies creams, but despite her efforts, RJ experiences painful symptoms and lacks sufficient sleep due to constant care. Misunderstandings about his appearance have led to public mistreatment, including accusations of child abuse and bullying from adults. Recently, a stranger falsely reported Valerie to the police for abusing RJ, resulting in a distressing encounter with armed officers.
