Valerie emphasizes the ignorance surrounding RJ's condition and highlights the challenges they face socially, as RJ is often excluded from activities and subjected to cruel comments. Despite these hardships, Valerie and her husband, Reginald, strive to care for RJ and advocate for better awareness of Netherton's syndrome.

Campaigners opposed to Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" adverts celebrating bikini model Renee Somerfield on the London Underground are pleased as Transport for London (TfL) announces their removal after a three-week period. The posters sparked significant backlash from feminists, body image advocates, and social media users, leading to over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). Defacement of the posters and threats, including a bomb threat under investigation by police, further fueled the controversy. Protein World defended the campaign by engaging on social media and emphasizing their goal to promote health and confidence. The ASA is currently assessing the complaints, while protests against the brand continue to gather support. Meanwhile, protein powder sales in the UK are rapidly increasing.

Rail companies faced criticism for planning fare increases of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, contradicting main party leaders' promises to freeze or cap prices. Prime Minister David Cameron specifically requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the London-Cotswolds route affecting his Witney constituency. Despite Cameron and Labour pledging to control rail fare hikes, other train firms also announced significant price increases, leading to anger among constituents and prompting Cameron's personal intervention.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his wife Elaine, 54, were attacked by vandals in their Oldham home when thugs threw bricks at their windows. While writing thank-you cards for their recent wedding, the assailants pelted their front window with stones, causing John to open the door and confront them. During the confrontation, a brick struck John's left eye, resulting in permanent blindness in that eye despite emergency surgery, and he also sustained an open forehead wound. The couple, who felt safe in their neighborhood until the incident three weeks after their marriage, are relocating due to fear for their safety. Police have launched an investigation but have not identified a clear motive, suggesting the attack may have been random.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, aged 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from leg injuries caused by a road accident in April, which also resulted in his father Keith's death. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season and underwent an ankle operation before making his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. He is now committed to the county through the end of the 2016 season and is expected to be available at the start of the season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing confidence in his continued good form and contributions to the team.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To cope with his intensive treatment, including chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley created and decorated a ninja turtle superhero mask, which strengthened his spirit during radiotherapy. His bravery and creative approach gained media attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon. After a year of battling the aggressive cancer, doctors have declared Harley cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups and hopes to return to school full time, bringing joy and optimism to his family.

Tim Sherwood urges Jack Grealish to prioritize his career at Aston Villa over his international prospects. The 19-year-old impressed in Villa's FA Cup semi-final victory against Liverpool and is now sought after by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood emphasizes the importance of Grealish securing a regular spot in Villa's first team before making a decision on his international future. Grealish's father, Kevin, supports focusing on club football first. Sherwood compares Grealish's situation to Nabil Bentaleb's choice between France and Algeria, highlighting that the final decision rests with Grealish after he gains more experience with Aston Villa.

The passage highlights the substantial landing fees associated with private jet travel, a luxury accessible only to the wealthy. These fees vary significantly across airports, with Japan's Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive at £4,559, followed by Narita and Kansai airports. Other notable high-fee airports include Salzburg (Austria), Darwin (Australia), Toronto Pearson (Canada), Bristol (England), Dublin (Ireland), and LaGuardia in New York. The private jet industry is rapidly expanding, recording 2.5 million flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe in 2013, and holding market values of $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. Peak travel times align with major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, leading to increased landing fees and higher flight costs.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her Labrador, Cooper, and his friend Daisy to a McDonald’s drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy enjoyed a few licks, Cooper quickly devoured his cone in one bite. The video of this outing has been viewed over seven million times. Although some viewers found the scene cute and funny, others criticized Gallegos for giving her dogs a creamy treat. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, defended her actions by stating that Cooper is healthy and shares that her late dog Sammy also enjoyed ice cream regularly. Additionally, Cooper and Daisy were featured in another video where they visited Starbucks for a “pup-uccino,” which Cooper also quickly consumed. Gallegos clarified that the pup-uccino contains only whipped cream without coffee.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year contract after a successful interim period. The 41-year-old former Hearts boss joined the club last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston but took over in February when Johnston resigned. Since assuming control at Rugby Park, Locke has lost only once in seven games. He is set to speak at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp from Eustis, accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because he uses Doterra essential oils on his neck to help him stay calm and focused. Teachers cited the oils' scents as distracting to other students. Despite receiving a letter from the local school board about the issue, the Lake County School District later decided not to suspend Logan, labeling it a health issue. Kemp intends to continue using the oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

On Wednesday at 3 pm, a severe fire destroyed the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, Hamptons, obliterating 90 condos and causing the building to collapse. The blaze, whose origin is under investigation and may have started near a parked car, was so intense that smoke was visible from three miles away and melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames using cranes but could not enter the summer homes. Residents, including building manager Rob Taber, lost everything and described the incident as unbelievable.

Despite approaching her 89th birthday, the 88-year-old Queen remains passionate about horseback riding. She was recently seen riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park without a helmet, preferring a silk scarf instead. The Queen has loved horses since childhood, owning various steeds over the years and currently breeds thoroughbreds and fell ponies at Hampton Court Stud. Although a knee injury has reduced her riding activities and participation in events like Trooping the Colour, she remains an active equestrienne at her Windsor stables. Additionally, the passage highlights the history and enduring popularity of fell ponies, a breed the Queen continues to support and breed.

A noise dispute between Brisbane neighbors ended tragically when 28-year-old Phillip Pama allegedly punched and killed his 55-year-old neighbor, Leon Yeaman. The incident occurred around 9 pm on Thursday night while Yeaman was making loud noises in his yard on Muller Road. Pama, a married father of three with no prior history of violence, confronted Yeaman, leading to the fatal punch. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail with restrictions, and the case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship for a classmate. She offered £1,400 and specified that she wanted Vanya to suffer severe injuries before being killed. Police conducted a sting operation in Shatura, secretly filming Simonova during the exchange. After handing over some money, she was arrested in her car and now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief after ending the relationship.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho shared that he communicates with God daily about personal matters, deliberately keeping his professional life separate from his family. He does not discuss football with his wife and focuses his prayers solely on his personal life rather than the sport. Mourinho, a father of two, is actively involved as an ambassador for the World Food Programme, addressing poverty and hunger. Despite his competitive and sometimes arrogant demeanor on the sidelines, he considers himself a good family man and friend. Currently, Chelsea is leading the league, and earlier in the season, Mourinho was fined £25,000 for alleging a campaign against the team.

Bob Barker returned to host "The Price is Right" for the first time in eight years during the April 1 episode. At 91, he led the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over hosting duties to Drew Carey. Despite his long absence since stepping down in 2007, Barker appeared energetic and seamlessly resumed his role.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday at 12:30 am for allegedly attempting to break into a residence on the 3200 block of D Street SE. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Following his arrest, Baldwin's security clearance was revoked, and he was placed on leave. He is assigned to the Foreign Missions branch of the Secret Service, which handles U.S. diplomatic activities. Baldwin was scheduled to be arraigned on Friday afternoon. His arrest occurs shortly after a high-ranking supervisor within the agency was also put on leave due to misconduct allegations, both of which are being investigated by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. These incidents negatively impact the reputation of the Secret Service, the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, entered a city safari park to photograph a hungry male lion. Armed only with a camera, he approached within 10 feet and captured a few frames. However, the camera's shutter sound alerted the lion, causing Atif to quickly retreat to his car as the lion charged. Although he initially found the encounter amusing, he later reflected that he wouldn't attempt such a risky situation again.

New York City Police are seeking to identify an unnamed woman, aged between 25 and 45, who died nearly a month ago on a Brooklyn street. She was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had no identification but featured a distinctive heart tattoo with the name "Monique" on her right leg. The NYPD has released images of the tattoo to aid in identifying her. Investigators are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck over a year and a half. Using wood and steel, their nearly self-sufficient home in Nelson features solar panels, a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and water from a nearby spring. The project cost about $25,000, allowing them to live with their cat surrounded by nature.

Researchers found that kindergarten students who share iPads in class scored approximately 30 points higher on early literacy tests compared to those without iPads or those using individual devices. Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University conducted the study with 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district, indicating that collaborative use of technology enhances literacy outcomes. These results challenge skepticism about using technology in non-IT classes and suggest that schools should reconsider tablet usage, especially in early grades. Blackwell is set to present her findings at the 65th annual International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet named "Super Pig," born without hind legs, has become an internet sensation in China for its ability to balance and walk on its front trotters. Owned by Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, the heartwarming video showcases the piglet's unsteady steps as it forages for food, captivating thousands despite occasional near-tumbles. The piglet happily interacts with its fully-legged siblings, attracting villagers and tourists alike, and joins other two-legged animals in China that have gained online popularity.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car struck his leg after spinning while exiting the pit box on lap 25. The incident occurred amid rain-affected conditions that caused many cars to struggle with traction. Dracone did not finish the race, finishing in 23rd place. Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was subsequently released.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his 29-year-old dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in Rio de Janeiro by smashing her head into concrete eleven times and shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime, citing jealousy of men looking at her as his motive and accusing her of being a "slut" and "whore." After the attack, Severiano attempted to escape in a neighbor's car but was arrested after crashing it. Police discovered four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his getaway vehicle. Severiano now faces life imprisonment.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for her best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," has revealed her personal struggle with mental illness, including a near-suicide experience driven by severe anxiety. At 41, Wilson discussed how mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family relationships made her feel isolated and saw no way forward. She has recently found some peace with her condition and highlighted the intrinsic link between depression and anxiety. Wilson advocates for greater awareness of this connection to address the increasing rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women, noting that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," with one in three Australian women expected to experience it in their lifetime.

In November 2014, Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon, who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault for beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in the bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law allowing force against intruders. Curtin gave birth in January, is now living with her parents, and avoided a potential six-year prison sentence.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed at home being fed treats when her owner added a broccoli spear to trick her. She reacted with disgust by chewing and spitting out the vegetable. Her owner hopes that the two children she lives with will not imitate her dislike of greens. Additionally, other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page instead of the now-shut Young Entrepreneur Awards page. The error occurred because the awards page, discontinued in 2011, allowed its URL on hsbc.com.hk to be taken over by a porn site. Upon discovering the issue, HSBC removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, assured the public that its website remained secure, and apologized for the inconvenience caused.

On Sunday morning in Clinton, Maryland, 13-year-old Marcus called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his family's home. During the 11-minute call, Marcus calmly provided instructions that helped firefighters locate and rescue him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah, who were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. He soothed his sister and guided responders by describing specific locations within the house. Firefighters entered by breaking a window and safely evacuated the siblings, who were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Meanwhile, their older brother, mother, and stepfather escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital. Marcus was praised for his heroic actions during the emergency.

Amazing images captured in Jervis Bay, New South Wales, showcase blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast beaches. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the scene as a "beautiful supernatural" display caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar natural phenomenon occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the glow is produced by the single-celled phytoplankton *Noctiluca scintillans*, which blooms in spring and autumn and emits light as a defense mechanism.

New genetic marker tests, such as EndoPredict, enable breast cancer patients to potentially avoid chemotherapy by assessing the tumor's aggressiveness and the risk of disease recurrence. After surgery, cancer cells are analyzed in a lab, allowing doctors to determine within days if a patient has a high or low risk of the cancer returning. For some women, a low-risk score (as low as five percent) suggests that chemotherapy may not significantly improve their prognosis, sparing them from its severe side effects. Although these tests currently cost around £2,500 and are mostly available privately, there are hopes for their inclusion in the NHS. Medical experts support the use of these tests to help patients make informed treatment decisions, moving away from the routine administration of chemotherapy. An example is Becca Cornford, who avoided chemotherapy after her tumor's low recurrence risk was confirmed by the EndoPredict test.

Over the past nine years, more than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors evacuated, and HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty," had at least one woman removed before its decommissioning last year. Additionally, eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, experienced emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence enforces a strict "no touching" rule at sea, indicating pregnancies likely occurred before boarding or during leave. In related events, Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member, prompting a military investigation and her replacement. Since 1990, women have served on Royal Navy ships, comprising around 9% of personnel in 2014, and made history in May by becoming the first female submariners. Between January 2006 and December 2013, nearly 100 female British soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan and Iraq due to pregnancy, adhering to strict military rules that prohibit mothers-to-be from serving in war zones. Most pregnancies occurred before deployment, though some may have happened during service.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence, raising terrorism concerns. The incident coincided with a Japanese court's approval to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a move unpopular due to fears of nuclear energy following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. The 50-centimeter-wide drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing cesium, was detected by a staff member and investigated by police. Although the cesium amount is not harmful, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed worries about potential future terrorist attacks using drones during events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Current Japanese drone regulations restrict flights near airports but lack restrictions in most of Tokyo, including government buildings, prompting calls for continuous review to address drone-related terrorism threats.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang, China, diligently cares for his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's by bringing her to work daily on the back of his motorbike. To ensure her safety, he ties a sash around both of their waists and rides slowly during their four-kilometer commute, which takes an hour, allowing them to chat along the way. After his father passed away and with no other caregivers available—his wife working in another city and his son still in school—Lu decided to take his mother to work to prevent her from getting lost, as she had previously wandered off when left alone. At his workplace, a bank, his mother is provided her own room, and he regularly checks on her to ensure she remains safe. Motivated by his mother's lifelong dedication to caring for her children, Lu feels a strong duty to reciprocate her devotion.

A study by the University of Washington’s Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, published in the *American Journal of Public Health*, found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, primarily due to a significant rise in women’s alcohol consumption. Heavy drinking is defined by the CDC as more than one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking involves four or more drinks for women and five for men on a single occasion. Women’s binge drinking rates surged nearly seven times faster than men’s nationwide, with examples like a 36% increase in Santa Clara County, California. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% engaged in binge drinking. The increase is attributed to changing social norms, greater affordability of alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. Additionally, excessive drinking resulted in approximately 88,600 deaths in 2010 and costs over $220 billion annually.

UN officials warn that doctors in England are performing caesarean sections excessively, with over 25% of births now via C-section—more than double since the early 1990s. They state that C-sections should only be done when medically necessary due to risks such as infections and death, and because the procedure is more costly (£2,369 versus £1,665 for natural births). The World Health Organization recommends an ideal C-section rate of 10–15%, opposing current NHS guidelines that allow the procedure without medical justification, including for women with high anxiety about childbirth. WHO highlights that the overuse of caesareans poses significant health risks to women and babies and diverts resources from other patients.

Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for breaking into an $800,000 Martha's Vineyard home owned by Mark Conklin. She lived in the property for at least a week, selling the owners' belongings through a yard sale. Charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, Filkins initially fled when confronted but was later apprehended when she tried to re-enter the home. Police are seeking the return of various stolen items and have scheduled her court appearance for May 14.

Albury police reunited Bella Crooke with her lost, unlocked iPhone by creatively posting selfies and humorous photos on her Facebook page. After Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party, a security guard handed it to the Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Noticing the phone was unlocked, officers used it to post messages and images, encouraging Bella to retrieve her device. Bella was able to reclaim her phone without providing her name, as the police recognized her through her Facebook profile. Her friends praised the police for their unusual and humorous approach, and Bella subsequently added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed during a fight between two adult males in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa. The calf wandered into the conflict zone, where it was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface. Despite the mother's efforts to protect her baby, the calf succumbed to its injuries hours later while the mother watched in horror.

A three-bedroom maisonette in London's prestigious Knightsbridge area is listed for £575,000, significantly below neighboring property prices. However, the flat has only three years remaining on its lease, resulting in an effective annual cost of £191,000, comparable to local rental rates. The 1,990 sq/ft property requires modernization and includes features such as a lift, parking, and a communal garden. Extending the lease with the freeholder, the Welcome Trust, could increase the property's value to over £6 million. Sold by Russell Simpson, this rare listing has attracted interest from locals, developers, and end users despite the high costs associated with the short lease and necessary renovations.

On Friday night, Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting approximately 8,000 stores in the US and Canada due to a failure during a daily system refresh. This disruption prevented credit card transactions, leading baristas to offer free drinks and baked goods to customers. While some locations remained open, others closed early to avoid further giveaways. The company announced that the issue has been resolved and stores would return to normal operations on Saturday. The outage occurred shortly after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings, and customers widely shared their experiences on social media.

Terrorists are being trained and radicalized in rural West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Individuals involved participate in ordinary community activities but have hidden extremist motives. Since 1998, areas like the Brecon Beacons have hosted extremist training by figures such as Abu Hamza. Notable incidents include the 7/7 bombers being photographed in Bala and the arrest of an al-Qaeda-inspired plot in Cardiff. Michael Adebowale, linked to the murder of Lee Rigby, studied at the European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanybydder. Authorities emphasize that terrorism threats in Wales are not limited to large cities and highlight the importance of community intelligence in addressing these issues.

A previously feared extinct Omura's whale was discovered washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia following tropical cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling, providing scientists an opportunity to study this recently described species, typically found in Indonesian, Philippine, and Sea of Japan waters. The carcass has been buried for future scientific investigation and possible display in museums.

The passage critiques Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman, who argues against Hillary Clinton's presidential candidacy by claiming her hormones could lead to irrational decisions and unnecessary wars. It counters her viewpoint by highlighting that male hormones have also impaired leaders and that women generally take fewer risks in leadership. The article emphasizes the pervasive gender bias in workplaces and society, which hinders women's potential despite their educational and professional achievements. It underscores the benefits of gender equality for the economy, families, and corporate success, and challenges the unfounded biases that prevent women from attaining leadership roles. Additionally, it corrects misinformation about Kim Campbell being Canada’s first female prime minister.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning his £100,000 antiques collection, which includes over 200 items such as a Battle of Agincourt diorama, Victorian cabinets, a yew longbow, and rare books, due to downsizing his home. The auction, organized by Dominic Winter in Gloucestershire, showcases items reflecting his interests in military history and classic literature. At 89, Hardy is renowned for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small," portraying Winston Churchill in multiple productions, and appearing as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films. Additionally, he is a published military historian and an expert on medieval longbows. Although he retired from stage acting after a fall, he continues to work in television.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man with a history of bipolar disorder and prior legal issues, is suspected of murdering his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, in their Winter Garden home. Shemansky has been on the run since Saturday after failing to attend a supervised visit with his son—the same day his mother was found dead following a suspected foul play investigation. Neighbors indicate that ongoing divorce proceedings and his mother's interference may have contributed to the incident. Authorities have obtained the murder weapon and are seeking information on his whereabouts, urging anyone with details to contact them at 407-656-3636.

Eugene, United States, has been selected to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council opted to bypass the usual bidding process, recognizing a unique strategic opportunity to hold the championships in the USA for the first time. Although Eugene's bid for the 2019 event was unsuccessful, losing to Doha, a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of the city's capability to host a world championship. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized that the decision leverages collaboration among public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the local community to support the global development of the sport.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger used her appearance to befriend Hassan at a London casino, receiving gifts and cash from him. She then collaborated with her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler to lure Hassan to his flat, where they tied him up and killed him to steal his winnings. While Granger was convicted of manslaughter, Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 36 years. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," highlighting the brutality of the crime.

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has struggled in the second half of the season, showing a significant decline in form both for his club and the Spanish national team. Despite expressing happiness in London and a strong start earlier in the season, his assist numbers have dropped sharply, and he received a low rating in Spain's 2-0 loss to Holland. Fatigue from playing every minute has affected his performance, raising concerns about his durability. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is worried about Fabregas's ability to remain a key player in the Premier League title race, although recent assists indicate a potential late-season improvement.

West Ham is close to signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial. Beckford has offers from Belgian and other European clubs and is considered a top Caribbean prospect. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the most affordable in the Barclays Premier League as they aim to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Three months after a severe assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman, Wiltshire Police have halted their investigation despite substantial evidence, including video footage and a dossier with suspect names and car registration numbers. The attack occurred during a hunt in Everleigh, where Lane was violently beaten by balaclava-clad protesters using iron bars and ropes, resulting in serious injuries and memory loss. Lane criticized the police decision as "pathetic" and expressed declining trust, while hunt supporters across the country were dismayed. Police stated the case is marked as undetected but may be reopened if new evidence emerges. The incident has also sparked calls from the Countryside Alliance to ban face coverings for saboteurs to aid in their identification and prosecution.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American known as "Azzam the American," served as al Qaeda's prominent English-language propagandist. Born in 1978 in rural California, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and joined al Qaeda in Pakistan in 1998. He gained notoriety through numerous al Qaeda videos in which he threatened attacks against the United States and other targets, urging Muslims to take violent actions against Western and Jewish interests. In 2006, Gadahn was indicted by a federal grand jury in California for treason and providing material support to al Qaeda, making him one of the FBI's most wanted terrorists. On January [year not specified], the White House announced that Gadahn was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation, along with another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, in what was likely a separate operation. Additionally, Warren Weinstein, a U.S. citizen abducted by al Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011, died in the attack that killed Farouq. Gadahn was married to a Muslim woman from Afghanistan and had at least one child.

Chinese parents are dedicated to cultivating child prodigies, including young talents like five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who has gained popularity through a viral video showcasing his exceptional basketball skills. Mai has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old and impressively demonstrates abilities such as scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His remarkable talents have attracted a large fanbase across basketball-enthusiastic China, drawing comparisons to former NBA star Yao Ming. The viral video has sparked widespread admiration and astonishment among netizens, many of whom have left thousands of comments praising Mai's potential and expressing envy over their own basketball skills in comparison.
I'm sorry, but I can't help with that.

On Thursday, Bondi's iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained to create a unique catwalk for Ten Pieces' presentation at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event featured a monochrome, unisex capsule collection designed to be worn in multiple ways, led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss. Models showcased minimalist, androgynous designs against an ocean backdrop, while guests and beachgoers enjoyed the sunny weather and watched the show from various vantage points.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. During the visit, he fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his upcoming fight against former light-welterweight champion Chris Algieri on May 30, dismissing speculation about potential matches with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman as he continues negotiations for other opponents.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, whose name was recently added to Jerusalem's Mount Herzl memorial, will have his name removed following objections from his family and the organization Almagor. Abu Khdeir, 16, was brutally killed by three Israelis in July, and his inclusion on the memorial, which honors fallen soldiers and terrorism victims, sparked controversy. His father stated that no permission was sought to add his son's name, and Almagor argued that Abu Khdeir's death was a rogue attack, not an act of terrorism. As a result, the National Insurance Institute of Israel decided to remove his name from the memorial, and legal proceedings against the suspects began in January.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, shared footage of his young son trying to use the family cat's belly as a pillow. The boy chased the cat around the garden, seeking a spot to rest, but each time he settled, the cat would move to a new location, prompting the boy to follow. After several attempts, the cat became tired of being used as a pillow and went indoors. In a subsequent video, the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

In an ongoing Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his history of selling marijuana. Kushner, one of over a dozen former drug dealers cooperating with the federal government, accused undercover officers of stealing $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana during a 2007 arrest. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, Kushner’s past arrests and probation became public, leading to his job loss. He expressed regret over his past actions and maintains his innocence regarding 2011 charges. Additionally, six former drug squad officers are facing a 26-count indictment that includes racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing.

An explosion at a paraxylene-producing chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, injured six people and ignited a large fire on Monday night following an oil leak. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze by Tuesday morning. The controversial plant, known for producing the carcinogenic chemical used in polyester fabrics, had previously experienced a similar explosion in July 2013. Although no toxic spills were reported, the facility has faced protests and was relocated in 2007 due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish addressed Premier League referees, insisting he won't "pull his socks up" despite their requests, citing superstition. The Aston Villa teenager is known for wearing his stockings low, just above his children's size shinpads, a habit he intends to maintain after his first Premier League start against QPR, which ended in a 3-3 draw. Grealish expressed gratitude for his manager's faith in him, believes he deserves his starting position, and hopes to earn more appearances as the season progresses.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has sustained global and irreversible brain damage. Although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and in the same neurological state for nearly three months, showing no reactions to visitors or familiar voices and requiring a tracheostomy. Her grandmother expressed sorrow over her lifelong condition and hopes for a miracle. Two days prior, her father Bobby Brown announced an improvement, stating that Bobbi is awake and watching him. An attorney confirmed her condition has improved and she has begun a long rehabilitation process, though the quality of her future life remains uncertain.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki by saving a match point with a score of 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. In the opening rubber, Svetlana Kuznetsova won against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Despite serving challenges—Pavlyuchenkova with 13 double faults and Lisicki committing 63 unforced errors—Russia is poised to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008 by winning one of the remaining three matches on Sunday.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for additional floods and damage as another storm, similar to last week’s east coast low, is expected to bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is overwhelmed with over 24,000 assistance requests and fears that the new storm will hinder ongoing clean-up efforts, particularly in the hard-hit Hunter region. Meteorologists forecast intense rainfall and strong winds mainly affecting coastal northeast areas, with peak conditions mid-week. Over 1,000 SES personnel, including 200 from other states, are deployed to manage the situation and urge residents to secure their homes and families in anticipation of the incoming weather system.

Nina Moric, a model featured in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, refuted Italian media reports claiming she attempted suicide. She explained that she collapsed from low blood pressure and was hospitalized due to a domestic accident. Moric shared images of bruising on her Instagram account with over 40,000 followers, assuring them she is recovering at home. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially confirmed the suicide attempt but Moric denied these claims, stating they were incorrect. Additionally, the passage mentions her former husband, Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzi who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times reveals that as Kate Middleton and Prince William prepare for their second child, the British public hopes they choose a traditional name. If the baby is a girl, **Diana** is the top preference at 12%, honoring William's late mother, followed by **Alice** and **Charlotte** with 9% each. For a boy, **James** leads with 13%, followed by **Alexander**. Among 2,200 respondents, a quarter favor a girl, while only 3% desire a younger brother for Prince George. Social media largely supports naming the baby Diana. Additionally, 68% of Britons approve of William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked protesters near Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday around 10 a.m., killing 17 and wounding dozens, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon. The protesters were en route to a rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final offer for a three-year contract extension, which required him to participate in 60% of matches. After seven successful years, during which he won four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back was unable to agree on a new deal with the Catalan club, ending negotiations.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old forward on loan from Southampton to Boca Juniors, has become a standout player by scoring three goals in six games. He has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to transfer to Boca Juniors, believing their South-American style and abilities would complement the team well. Osvaldo is confident that Boca fans at La Bombonera would greatly appreciate having Pirlo and Totti on the pitch, highlighting Pirlo's status as a top midfielder and Totti's legendary reputation from Roma.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson became an internet sensation after a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during the 4.20 pm race at Wincanton. The fall, which resulted in a cut on his nose, was watched hundreds of thousands of times online. Despite the ordeal, Ferguson returned to Paul Nicholls's yard the following Thursday morning to continue his usual duties without special treatment. He described the fall as a blur, received support from fellow jockeys, gained a few hundred Twitter followers, and humorously considered pursuing a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, captain of London Wasps and an England flanker, celebrated the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron" by dressing as Iron Man in an Instagram post. The movie premiered at Westfield London, featuring stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and the Highlanders in New Zealand. Since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 England caps.

The wide leg trouser is becoming a prominent Spring/Summer 2015 trend, available in styles like denim, cropped, printed, and striped. Seen as an effortless alternative to skinny jeans, this look harks back to the 1970s and is endorsed by figures such as Louise Redknapp and brands like Gucci, Topshop, Celine, and Stella McCartney. To achieve a flattering appearance, it’s recommended to pair wide-leg trousers with high-heeled shoes and simple tops, ensuring proper proportion and elongation of the legs. The trend offers both casual and dressy options, making it a versatile addition to wardrobes and accessible through various labels and online retailers.

The University of Michigan will proceed with screening "American Sniper" as part of UMIX despite over 200 students petitioning against it. Critics were concerned the film's portrayal of the Iraq War and the Middle East could negatively impact Detroit's large Arab-American community. After facing backlash and a counter-petition, the university's Vice President for Student Life reversed the initial cancellation, emphasizing freedom of expression. Additionally, UMIX will offer the family-friendly film "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper." The decision received praise from head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

On April 3, two French men aged 18 and 24 attempted to set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter. The quokka was singed but survived the incident. Authorities seized video evidence, evicted the men from the island, and charged them with animal cruelty. The suspects will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at New York nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s, performed alongside notable figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Although motion pictures of her existed, she had never seen them, and her photographs and memorabilia were lost over time. With assistance from filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers, a video using early music videos ("soundies") was created and shown to Barker at her nursing home. The ageless dancer was delighted, describing the experience as "just fabulous."

A recent study by OSV indicates that washing one’s own car is declining in Britain. Thirty-one percent of men and seventy-five percent of women have never washed their vehicles personally, with only twelve percent of men doing so regularly. Most drivers prefer using local car wash services due to factors like increased availability of car washes, busier weekends from shops and televised football, and the difficulty of cleaning larger vehicles. Additionally, regional differences exist, with cities like Birmingham and Sheffield seeing higher rates of owner-washed cars compared to Oxford and Edinburgh. During holidays, more Brits wash their cars, often using it as an opportunity to go out. Popular brands such as Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are more frequently washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are cleaned less often.

Martin Skrtel has commended Steven Gerrard's profound influence and leadership at Liverpool since his arrival in 2008, recognizing Gerrard as one of the world's premier players and integral to the club's identity. Gerrard is set to captain Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead the team to the final against Arsenal. Should Liverpool win, Gerrard will retire from Anfield on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Despite his departure, Skrtel is confident that Liverpool can effectively replace Gerrard, citing the presence of potential successors. Additionally, both Gerrard and Skrtel may return to play in the upcoming match against Villa after serving suspensions for a previous incident.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus made a hole in one during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National, showcasing his enduring golfing skill. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw as Masters week began, Nicklaus achieved his first ace on Augusta's turf by sinking a 130-yard shot on the fourth hole, delighting the crowd. Although his accomplishment was notable, it was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who recorded multiple hole-in-ones that day. The passage also highlights Nicklaus's historic achievements, including being the youngest to wear a green jacket in 1963, winning his sixth in 1986, and being one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Several tornadoes were reported in Kansas on Wednesday night, including one near Goddard, approximately 17 miles west of Wichita. While the tornado missed Wichita, it posed risks to nearby communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of ongoing dangerous nighttime storms. Additional tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna and possibly in Potosi, Missouri, near St. Louis, where wind damage and flooding were observed. Social media users reported fallen trees, roof damage, flooding, and large hail. The National Weather Service forecasted more storms for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River Valleys, and the southern Great Lakes.

Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the fatal shooting of Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims he intended to use a taser but accidentally shot Harris and has apologized to the family, alongside Sheriff Stanley Glanz. During the preliminary hearing, the judge allowed Bates to vacation in the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as insensitive. The family also alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and connections, though the Tulsa County Sheriff’s Office denies these claims. Bates' lawyers released training documents supporting his qualifications, and two other deputies involved in the arrest were reassigned following threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is set to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, McGregor revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach and posted a message on Instagram emphasizing his superior motivation compared to Aldo's eighth title defense. During a March promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor publicly grabbed and raised Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 supporters, underscoring their tense relationship as they approach the upcoming bout.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after he skolled a schooner of beer at an Australian rules football event, where about 50 people cheered and chanted "skol" and "Tony." Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, condemned Abbott for glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. Critics argued that Abbott should set a positive example without promoting irresponsible drinking practices. In contrast, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended the Prime Minister, suggesting his actions demonstrated fitness and a healthy lifestyle. Additionally, opposition leader Bill Shorten mocked Abbott’s drinking habits, highlighting the controversy surrounding the incident.

Indiana has experienced a significant rise in HIV cases in Scott County, increasing from 106 to 120 confirmed and adding 10 preliminary cases since Governor Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program on March 26. The outbreak, primarily linked to the intravenous use of the painkiller Opana, involves 86 participants who have received over 5,300 clean syringes, with approximately 1,400 used syringes returned. Health officials anticipate further increases as more individuals are tested. Governor Pence is considering extending the 30-day program beyond April 25 based on recommendations. The situation has sparked debate over the expansion of needle exchange programs in other counties, balancing harm reduction efforts against concerns that such programs may promote drug use. Funding and legislative support remain uncertain, with federal bans on public funding for needle exchanges since 1989 complicating long-term sustainability.

An enthusiastic Arsenal fan required his girlfriend, Saskia, to complete a comprehensive test about the football club. The exam included multiple-choice questions, tables, and open-ended sections, covering topics like team history, player positions, and match details. Saskia scored an impressive 87%, earning praise from her boyfriend, who stated he wouldn't end the relationship because of her performance. She shared her experience on Twitter, expressing mixed emotions about the rigorous exam. While many football fans lauded the boyfriend as a "legend" and deemed Saskia "proper gf material" for her knowledge, some critics felt he went overboard. Despite a few incorrect answers and playful feedback from her boyfriend, the overall response highlighted the couple's strong bond and shared passion for Arsenal.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia to escape threats to his life. In exchange for his cooperation, which included providing crucial information that led to the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, Toro was promised U.S. citizenship. However, upon retiring due to declining health, his temporary visa expired, leaving him in the U.S. illegally as the DEA has refused to assist with his citizenship. Faced with deportation, Toro fears for his safety in Colombia and is currently unable to obtain a green card or passport, preventing him from accessing social security benefits. Support from former DEA agent Mike McManus and colleagues has provided some financial aid, but Toro remains uncertain about his future in the United States.

A 14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan in Uttar Pradesh, India, allegedly was gang-raped by five men while relieving herself. Following the assault, her family reportedly urged her to remain silent. In protest, she set herself on fire using kerosene and is now recovering with 70% burns at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital. The five accused men have been arrested. This incident occurs amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, highlighted by the recent banning of the documentary "India's Daughter," which detailed the gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh and led to widespread protests. Additionally, other violent acts against alleged rapists, such as the public beating and killing of Syed Sarif Khan in Nagaland, reflect the country's intense anger over misogyny and have sparked demands for increased protection for women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal aims to defeat Manchester City in Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford to help his team finish second or third in the league, avoiding a Champions League qualifying spot. Despite Robin van Persie declaring fitness, Van Persie will miss the match due to ankle trouble, and Luke Shaw is also ruled out for fitness reasons. Van Gaal emphasized the importance of winning to achieve their seasonal goals and acknowledged City as strong opponents without seeking revenge for a previous loss. Training sessions featured key players like Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, Angel Di Maria, and Radamel Falcao. Van Gaal expressed optimism about the derby atmosphere and praised the support from United’s fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested at the Emirates Stadium during a sold-out Premier League match by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes. The demonstration opposed rising ticket prices, with tickets starting at £64, following the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Supporters expressed disgust over escalating costs, fearing it may alienate fans and harm the sport's integrity. Banners displayed messages like "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket," highlighting their struggle to afford attending games. Organizers from both fan groups criticized the prioritization of money over fan experience and called for tangible ticket price reductions to preserve the football community.

Newborn Star Reader from Barnsley was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a severe liver condition, shortly after birth. After an initial surgery to unblock her bile ducts failed, Star needed a liver transplant to survive. With neither parent being a suitable match, her maternal aunt and her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver. The successful November operation allowed Star to recover after six weeks in the hospital. She now continues with regular medical care and can lead a normal life, thanks to Shanell's life-saving donation.

This season, Chelsea has been successful both on and off the pitch. Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in Audi's Football Challenge, competing against teammates Loic Remy and Willian. In the initial rounds, Hazard and Ake won by shooting footballs into car boots and performing well on a makeshift tennis court using an Audi R8 V10 Plus as the net, leading to a 6-0 advantage after two rounds. In the final challenge, Remy and Willian secured a surprise victory by sinking footballs from long range. During their win, Willian accidentally smashed an Audi's wing mirror but is not expected to bear the repair costs.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a fatal highway crash on December 7, 2013, by driving his pickup truck over a median at over 100 mph into an oncoming SUV. The accident killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, her 29-year-old fiancé Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal, contradicting earlier claims that he intended to kill himself. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger's wife testified to his integrity and serious health problems, while his attorneys cited mental health issues, including Ambien withdrawal and multiple sclerosis, as factors in the crash.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paulf Spears, who died from salt poisoning. During the sentencing, Spears appeared emotionless, while her ex-husband, Chris Hill, publicly criticized her on Facebook, urging that she be placed in general population and expressing a desire for her to die in prison. Prosecutors argued that Spears intentionally poisoned her son’s feeding tube to gain attention, leading to his prolonged suffering and death. Spears' lawyer described her as a hardworking single mother who loved her son unconditionally and plans to appeal the verdict, claiming innocence and blaming the hospital for negligence. The judge acknowledged Spears' mental illness but deemed the crime's cruelty as unfathomable.

Fears of two new influenza strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, causing increased deaths in Europe and the US have led to an improved flu vaccine arriving in Australia a month later than expected. The updated vaccine includes protection against these strains as well as H1N1 and will be available for free to high-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians, starting April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, recommend everyone get vaccinated to better protect vulnerable populations and prevent further deaths.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending the site against a negative review in National Geographic and facing potential budget cuts amid Illinois' financial crisis. Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, threatening its management during the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. National Geographic criticized the tomb for lacking historical character, a view supported by historian Adam Goodheart, while supporters argue the critique is unfair and highlight over $2.5 million in recent renovations. Funding cuts have also reduced the tomb’s operating hours and staffing, causing concern among preservation advocates.

Nineties fashion is experiencing a resurgence, with trends like chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo T-shirts becoming popular among a new generation. The anticipated comeback of jnco’s wide-leg 'rave' jeans has alarmed former fans due to their impracticality. The passage highlights nine retro styles from the nineties and early 2000s—such as bucket hats, camouflage prints, double denim, ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers—that are being revived or maintained today by celebrities like Rihanna, Kylie Jenner, Selena Gomez, and others.

A busy week of trending stories included:

- **New York Rainbows:** After heavy rainfall, four rainbows appeared in the early morning sky, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company.
  
- **China's Crackdown on Vice:** Rural China has stopped hiring exotic dancers for wakes as part of a broader crackdown on vice, forcing families to find new ways to cheer up mourners.
  
- **Robert Downey Jr. Interview:** RDJ became agitated during a Channel 4 UK interview when questioned about his private life.
  
- **Kardashian-Inspired Trends:** The Kardashians launched the #kyliejennerchallenge, a lip plumping trend intended to mimic Kylie Jenner's look.
  
- **Alice Barker's Time Travel:** With filmmakers' assistance, 102-year-old Alice Barker revisited the past.
  
- **Controversial Prom Proposal:** A bomb-themed promposal led to accusations of racism when one school rejected it.
  
- **Ewan McGregor in 'Beauty and the Beast':** McGregor was announced to play Lumière, generating significant social media interest.
  
- **Johnny Depp's 'Black Mass' Trailer:** Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the trailer, showcasing his acting versatility.
  
- **Creative Pregnancy Announcements:** Ideas like referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and a military dad photobombing his son gained attention for originality.

At the Miami Open, Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets, advancing to the semi-finals where she will face either Sloane Stephens or Simona Halep. Her milestone achievement was marked with a giant celebratory cake, contributing to widespread festivities at the event. Additionally, Andy Murray reached his 500th win the day before, also celebrated with a large cake. Serena's attempt to meet her sister Venus in the tournament was ended when Venus was defeated by Carla Suarez Navarro, but Serena remains focused on progressing in what feels like a hometown event.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent human rights activist and owner of the second floor cafe (t2f) in Karachi, Pakistan, was assassinated by gunmen after hosting discussions on technology, human rights, and sensitive topics like Balochistan. Her cafe was a vibrant hub for secular and progressive thought, attracting many young Pakistanis seeking freedom of expression. Mahmud's fearless advocacy for free speech and progressive values made her a national figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance. Her death, which also injured her mother, has caused widespread grief and highlighted the dangers faced by those promoting non-violence and progressive ideals in Pakistan.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee, has lived in poverty for nearly seven decades in Jammu and Kashmir, India’s only Muslim-majority state. Fleeing violence during the 1947 Partition of India, Ram and approximately 100,000 West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) have been denied citizenship rights, preventing them from owning property or voting in state elections. This exclusion has confined multiple generations to slum conditions and limited opportunities. With the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) gaining power in Kashmir, there is renewed hope that the WPRs' status will be normalized and their rights restored. Activists emphasize that granting state-subject rights is essential for improving their circumstances, while also warning of potential unrest if their demands are not met. The region remains conflicted, balancing its prosperity against ongoing tensions between different communities.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer after the club made an offer of approximately £4 million, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Chelsea plans to loan Muto to their partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season, but the 22-year-old aims to join a team where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Muto recently scored the winning goal against Shonan Bellmare and emphasized his desire to carefully choose a club that supports his growth. Former FC Tokyo manager Ranko Popovic praised Muto's intelligence, speed, and confidence, suggesting he could thrive at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has acknowledged awareness of Muto but highlighted that Chelsea focuses on acquiring quality players or promising prospects while adhering to financial fair play regulations. Additionally, Chelsea's interest in Muto is linked to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre manufacturer Yokohama Rubber.

Australia has commendably abandoned its restrictive policy of excluding overseas-based players, allowing the selection of top talent regardless of where they play. This progressive move contrasts with England's outdated approach, where coach Stuart Lancaster limits selection to players in domestic clubs. The passage highlights successful examples like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell from Toulon, Steffon Armitage’s improved performance after moving to France, and Jonny Wilkinson’s enhancement post his move abroad. It argues that selecting the best available players, irrespective of their club location, is crucial for England’s success in the World Cup. Additionally, it points out that other nations, such as South Africa and Wales, effectively include their overseas stars, benefiting their national teams. The overall message praises Australia’s strategy and urges England to adopt a similar inclusive selection policy to ensure a competitive and victorious World Cup campaign.

Open Garden's Firechat app enables users to communicate without internet or mobile signals by creating wireless mesh networks using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) on iOS and a similar feature on Android. With over five million downloads, Firechat offers "everyone" and "nearby" chatrooms, allowing messages to pass through each phone acting as a network node within a range of up to 200 feet. To enhance these networks, Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that serves as a beacon or booster, improving message transmission across the mesh network. Currently compatible with Firechat within a 20-foot range, Greenstone can store up to 1,000 messages and has a one-year battery life. It is still under development, with plans to collaborate with manufacturers for broader availability. Greenstone is intended for use in communities, events, and areas prone to network congestion, ensuring resilient communication even without traditional connectivity.

Lillian Bushel, a 5'3" married burlesque performer from New Jersey, seeks to eliminate negativity around the word "fat" by embracing it as a positive self-description. In her recent TED Talk, she explained that terms like "short" and "wife" are honest descriptors of her identity, and "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly." Lillian highlighted that size discrimination in the workplace has increased by 66% over the past 30 years and that young girls often wish to be thinner. She believes that exposure to diverse body types enhances acceptance and prefers to showcase fuller figures through her burlesque performances. Since beginning her burlesque career in 2012 at 240 lbs, Lillian has found empowerment and improved self-esteem. Her TED Talk, uploaded three weeks ago, has received nearly 38,000 views with predominantly positive feedback, reinforcing her optimism that the body positivity movement is gaining traction.

Theo Walcott has mostly been on Arsenal’s substitute bench this season, appearing in 17 of 33 Premier League games and recently coming on in a 0-0 draw against Chelsea. Despite limited playing time, he participated in a Lanvin photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and model Olga Sherer. Walcott is hoping to make his first Arsenal start since March 14 in the upcoming match against Hull at the KC Stadium.

Legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker is auctioning his collection of over 400 props and puppets from more than 50 film productions, including **Men in Black**, **Batman Forever**, and **How the Grinch Stole Christmas**. Valued at approximately **$746,100**, the auction will take place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online on **May 29** via propstore.com. Notable items, such as the Alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black* and the Grinch costume, are expected to sell for over **$40,000** each. Baker's 30-year career includes work on iconic films like *An American Werewolf in London* and *Planet of the Apes*, making this auction a unique opportunity for collectors and fans to own a piece of Hollywood history.

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell tragically died while skiing with his family in Flaine, French Alps. During their last run, Carwyn became separated from his mother after his nine-year-old sister lost her skis. Attempting to reach the resort through dense woodland, he fell over a 164-foot drop. Police found his body by following his footprints in the snow. Carwyn, described as daring, outgoing, and a competent skier, was beloved by his family, friends, and school community. His death has left his family devastated, creating a "vast void in their hearts."

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to intense pressure to achieve a "size zero" figure and bullying about her weight. She became obsessed with her appearance, hiding food and surviving on as little as one piece of fruit daily, which led to her collapsing from starvation and being placed on a heart machine. After a week on intensive care, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery through eating disorder teams and mental health services. Her improved body image and confidence allowed her to reach the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, moving away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool unveiled their new home kit at Anfield, featuring a gingham design by New Balance under a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal. Players Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet presented the kit to fans, emphasizing the message "hold nothing back." Fans expressed strong support for Sterling to remain at the club despite recent transfer rumors. The new kit includes tributes to the Hillsborough disaster with the memorial flame and number 96. Additionally, Liverpool focused on their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, highlighting the team's commitment to success with the support of their passionate fans.

University of Manchester researchers, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter to date, covering 0.4% of the sky. This map, produced using data from the Dark Energy Survey's Dark Energy Camera on the Blanco Telescope in Chile, identifies dark matter clumps through gravitational lensing of 130 million galaxies. The project aims to expand the map to 12.5% of the sky over five years, enabling a 3D view of dark matter distribution to study galaxy formation and the nature of dark energy.

Manchester United has officially pursued PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old Memphis Depay, aiming to make him one of manager Louis van Gaal's first summer signings. Van Gaal, who previously included Depay in the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup squad, is keen on acquiring the prolific winger, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league matches this season. PSV, the Eredivisie champions, successfully defended their title by defeating Heerenveen 4-1, marking their first championship in seven years. Despite Tottenham's rejected £15 million offer last summer, Manchester United, along with Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club, are now competing to sign Depay, whose performances have drawn comparisons to stars like Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay's exceptional skills and athleticism have made him a standout player, attracting significant interest from top-tier clubs.

Chelsea triumphed with a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth side at the Academy Stadium. Tammy Abraham opened the scoring with two impressive volleys, securing Chelsea's first-half lead. Dominic Solanke added a third goal late in the match, solidifying Chelsea's commanding position. Despite Manchester City's efforts to equalize, highlighted by goals from Kean Bryan and Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, Chelsea's robust attack and solid defense prevailed. The match featured notable performances from both teams' young talents, with Chelsea showcasing their offensive strength and Manchester City displaying resilience until the final whistle.

Marco Rubio stated that sexual preference is innate but believes marriage definitions should be determined by state legislatures rather than courts, opposing same-sex marriage as a constitutional right. Despite his stance, he committed to attending same-sex weddings of family or staff members to support them. As a Catholic, he opposes divorce but maintains love for divorced individuals. Recently announcing his presidential campaign, Rubio has secured over $51 million in donations to compete in the primary against well-funded Republican candidates.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, a Spanish-Latvian couple, left their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue their dream of exploring the world by bicycle. Since starting their journey nearly a year ago, they have cycled almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, including France, Spain, Italy, and Turkey. They keep their expenses minimal by camping, using platforms like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers for accommodation, and living on less than three euros each per day, primarily spending on food. Their journey involves carrying all their gear, often pitching tents in scenic locations, and they document their experiences on their blog, "thecrazytravel." Looking ahead, they plan to continue cycling into Asia and eventually traverse the American continent.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 alleges that their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed the racial slur "poor n ***** party" on photo booth snapshots from their event. Unaware of the offensive inscriptions until months later, the couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, is suing Evans under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied the allegations and refused to apologize, prompting the couple to seek legal action despite initially not wanting to file a lawsuit. Mediation is set for the next morning, with a trial scheduled for July if no agreement is reached. The couple primarily seeks an apology from Evans.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recover from a recent concussion, causing him to withdraw from Harlequins' match against Saracens. Following his knockout during England's victory over Italy and experiencing persistent headaches after a game against France, Brown prioritized his health based on increased awareness from concussion education modules. He emphasized the importance of not rushing back to avoid long-term issues, similar to other players like George North and Johnny Sexton who have faced extended recovery periods. Additionally, Brown participated in the launch of Land Rover’s "We Deal in Real" campaign, which focuses on promoting awareness and safety regarding concussions in rugby.

Research by Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University suggests that increased smartphone and internet use may be causing a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among British couples. In his book "Sex by Numbers," he reveals that typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times a month, decreasing from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to factors such as the blending of public and private lives, constant email checking, technological connectivity leading to busier lifestyles, blurred boundaries between home and work, and competing demands on time, all of which reduce opportunities for couples to spend quality time together.

Tibetan Mastiffs, previously fetching up to £1.2 million in China as status symbols, have become unpopular and are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather due to a significant decline in their value. This downturn is largely attributed to the Chinese government’s anti-corruption crackdown, which curtailed the practice of gifting these dogs to officials, and recent bans in several cities on owning dogs over 50 kg. Additionally, rapid urbanization has made the breed less suitable for city life. Breeders have also contributed to the decline by cross-breeding for profit, resulting in lower-quality dogs. Animal welfare issues have emerged, with reports of cruelty in the transportation of Tibetan Mastiffs to abattoirs.

A survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that every female respondent experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half encountering it before age 18. Harassment ranged from verbal insults and intimidating behavior to sexual assault and rape. Consequently, 60% of women fear being attacked on public transit, leading many to alter their daily routines to avoid confrontation. The pervasive issue, often unreported, restricts women’s freedom and excludes them from public spaces. The findings prompted calls for a campaign to eliminate sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains. Officials emphasized the need for better education and stricter penalties to address and prevent such harassment.
